## Introduction

The Elimisha (Sponsorship) program seeks to promote education among the under privileged (orphaned or in strenuous economic conditions) children in Kibera community. The program aims to educate, empower and engage the children for a sustainable future. Kibera currently has 117 children in the program, 60 girls and 57 boys, 51 Children are in Primary School, 55 in High School, 4 in University and 7 in College. We have 86 students in public schools and 31 in private schools.

## School Update

### Activities and Outputs

-   All the fee payments have been done up to date. There has been an increase in some of the school fees, especially the grade 7 students.

-   71 families of the sponsored children were visited in the last six months and most of them were doing well other than the hard-economic time they are going through.

-   All sponsored children in Primary and Secondary School have received a set of New school uniforms given out in April.

-   Tuition classes

-   Picnic and hot lunch

-   All 115 families were given foodstuff worth Ksh. 1500/= each for Christmas.

-   All 115 sponsored children were given gifts for Christmas (the Christmas Love box)

#### Resources and inputs

### Outcomes

-   There is a high rate (93.2%) in school attendance

    -   109 Students out of 117 students attended school throughout the school term, 4 students were absent due to sickness, 2 student missed school due to indiscipline cases and 2 were absent due to other challenges (Fee arears and school transfers)

![Niko and Sylvia visiting a sponsored student (centre) at school](images/2023H1%20Elimisha%20Niko%20Sylvia.jpg)

-   Of the 117 students, 87 students (74%) performed above average and 29 students performed below average. One Students did not do the exams due to an indiscipline case.

-   Eighteen grade 8 students graduated to high school.

-   Five students successfully completed high school in December, they will join university or college in September 2023.

## University/College Update

3 students are in University, 1 has finished and is waiting for graduation by the end of the year.

## Mentorship Update

### Activities and Outputs

-   All children were involved in 4 general group mentorship sessions with Spur Team Members. Discussion topics were: self-esteem, peer pressure, resilience.

-   We had 55 sponsored children attending one-on-one mentorship sessions (an average of 2 meetings per child). We had an average of 18 mentorship sessions every month for the last 6 months.

-   We had 8 group mentorship sessions with different groups of the sponsored children:

    -   One session for grade 8

    -   One session for grade 7

    -   One session for high school girls

    -   Two sessions with post high school students.

    Discussion topics were: self-esteem, how to pray, personal hygiene and resilience.

-   We had a Cross Over mentorship program for 18 grade eight students in January. We met them for 13 days for 4 hours each day. Topics discussed were creating vision boards, spiritual growth, leadership, focus, resilience, personal hygiene, responsibility, values, and beliefs.

-   We had 4 students who had an average of 2 counselling sessions each with a Volunteer Counsellor.

![Having a group discussion during school break at the Spur Centre](images/2023H1%20Elimisha%20Group%20Discussion.jpg)

#### Resources and inputs

-   Spur Staff & Volunteers

-   Mentors 

-   Counsellors

### Outcome and Impact

-   Improved good behaviour/character e.g. *M*.

-   The children are more confident when expressing themselves e.g. *S*, *M* and *H*.

## School Holiday Programs

-   We had two picnics at Rowerland scouts camp in January and April during the school breaks.

-   We had one Hot Lunch at the Spur Afrika centre with 102 of our sponsored children.

## Medical Clinic

### Activities and Outputs

-   Held a one-day medical clinic for 114 Elimisha children in January.

    -   Doctors' consultations

    -   Weight and height measurements, checking temperature

    -   Art and colouring activities

-   Did oral hygiene education with the children and gave them toothbrush and toothpaste.

#### Resources and inputs

-   Spur Afrika partnered with Kibera Human Development Project Clinic (Dr. Simiyu)

-   7 Spur staff

-   7 Doctors

-   4 Nurses

-   15 volunteers

-   Finances

### Outcome and impact

-   The clinic found that the general Health of the children was good with minor ailments like skin rashes, coughs and headaches noted and treated.

-   The general health of the children is better. From January to June, 8 children got sick and received medical attention from different hospitals.

-   More children are brushing their teeth correctly leading to a decrease in dental problems.

## Challenges faced in the last six months

-   Increase in school fee in all schools due to due to inflation and governments introduction of Junior high school (grade 7) who are paying double of what we used to pay previous year.

-   We are still struggling with a few parents (6) who need frequent reminder to perform their parental responsibilities like picking up school report cards and following up on their children.

-   We have had 2 indiscipline cases from the Spur children.

-   Some of the children need to be more committed and put more effort in their studies.

-   70% of parents are going through hard economic times because they don’t have stable jobs and the cost of everything is going up.

-   Family conflicts between parents (gender-based violence) and separation which affects the children negatively.

## Budget update

-   Funds used so far in the last 6 months is **Ksh.  4,267,000** which is approximately **AUD 42,700.** This includes cost of school fees paid, one picnic for 115 sponsored children and the salary for one full time worker.

-   The funds utilised so far are within the budget.

## Plans for the next six months

-   Proposed spending in the next 6 months (2023) is projected at **Ksh. 3,050,000**, which is approximately **AUD 30, 500.**  This will include payment of one term of school fees, a five-day end year camp for 15 sponsored children and salary for one full time worker.

-   Spur Afrika Plan for the second half of the year will be:

    -   **Third term School fee payment**

    -   **School & Home Visit**

    -   **Annual 5 days Camp,**

    -   **Annual performance review of the children.**

    -   **Christmas Bucket**
